intro: Corydalis ambigua subsp. amurensis, commonly known as the Amur Corydalis, is a perennial herb native to the Russian Far East and parts of northeastern China. It belongs to the family Papaveraceae and is characterized by its slender stems and clusters of small, pink to purple flowers. The plant produces capsule fruits that contain numerous small, elongated seeds. It thrives in moist, shaded environments such as forest floors and stream banks. Its foliage consists of alternate, trifoliate leaves with lance-shaped lobes.
